syntaxPhrases.description: Indirect question introduced by quo usque tandem

text.vocab: how long? to what point? how far?

morphology.notes: Used to ask 'how long' or 'to what extent' - introduces a question

text.syntax: interrogative adverb limiting 'usque', forms compound expression 'quo usque'
text.style: Part of emphatic opening question for rhetorical effect
text.rhetoric: Opens the famous invective with temporal/spatial questioning, building emotional intensity
text.etymology: Originally ablative singular neuter of interrogative pronoun quis, used adverbially

text.vocab: all the way, right on, as far as, continuously

morphology.grammar: adverb of extent in time or place
morphology.notes: Modifies 'quo' to mean 'how long' or 'up to what point'

text.syntax: Forms compound interrogative 'quo usque' with quo, sometimes written as single word 'quousque'
text.rhetoric: Strengthens the opening interrogation, part of the climactic buildup
text.etymology: Can govern accusative as preposition meaning 'as far as, up to'

morphology.notes: Emphasizes the question - 'how long AT LAST will you...?'

text.syntax: Strengthens 'quo usque' and emphasizes the whole question for rhetorical effect
text.style: Often stands in close conjunction with other adverbs for emphasis
text.rhetoric: Corresponds to Greek particle δή for emphasis, creates emotional urgency and exasperation

text.vocab: you will abuse, misuse, take advantage of

morphology.grammar: 2nd person singular future indicative deponent verb
morphology.notes: Deponent verb - passive form but active meaning. Takes ablative object.

text.syntax: Future tense (not present abuteris) - parallel with following futures eludet, iactabit
text.style: Cicero prefers -re ending over -ris in future indicative passive/deponent
text.rhetoric: Future tense suggests ongoing, persistent abuse - not just present moment

morphology.grammar: vocative case - used for direct address
morphology.notes: The person being spoken to directly - 'O Catiline!'

text.syntax: Vocative case of direct address, creating personal confrontation
text.style: Strategic placement after the verb for dramatic effect
text.rhetoric: Direct apostrophe to the enemy, making the attack personal and immediate

morphology.grammar: ablative case - direct object of the deponent verb abutere

text.syntax: Ablative object of abutor - one of the verbs requiring ablative instead of accusative
text.style: Delayed until end of clause for emphasis
text.rhetoric: Personifies Roman restraint as something being violated and exploited
text.etymology: From patiens (present participle of patior 'to suffer, endure')

morphology.notes: Shows it's 'our patience' - the Roman people's patience

text.syntax: Possessive adjective in agreement with patientia (ablative singular feminine)
text.style: Emphasizes collective Roman identity against individual threat
text.rhetoric: Creates us-versus-him dynamic, appeals to collective Roman values and solidarity
